bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Henry Rose Carter, August 9, 1917

div1.p: Gorgas requests that Carter go to South America in order to continue his yellow fever work for the Rockefeller Foundation. He mentions the work of Guiteras and Wrightson.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Henry Rose Carter, August 9, 1917
div1.opener:
Y. F./Miss
Gorgas
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
August 9, 1917.
Dr. Henry R. Carter,
Public Health Service
Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Maryland.
My dear Carter:
div1.p:
Yours of August the fifth is
acknowledged. Dr. Rose sent me a cable-
gram the other day from Guiteras which
would seem to indicate that he had given up.
The wording was ambiguous. As soon as I
hear anything definite I will let you know.
I am very anxious to push the work and if
you are able to go I would like to have you
go down even if Guiteras does not go, and
push the work yourself. If you think you
can go I will take the matter up at once with
the Foundation. Welsh spoke to me the other
day about an excellent pathologist whom he
thought I could get, and if you can think of
C1
B23
anybody else who would be useful I would
be glad to discuss the matter with the
Foundation. I think it would be better
to have a party of three or four who would
keep each other company.

Mrs. Gorgas got a nice long letter
from Laura; Wrightson will serve with the
Camp at Annapolis Junction; it is in a
bad way from a malaria point of view.

Mrs. Gorgas joins me in kindest re-
gards to both yourself and Mrs. Carter.
